dict.string: Define the nearest grid position that regions snap to when you move or resize them.
Define how regions behave when dragged to overlapping positions.
Open the New Tracks dialog, where you can add audio, instrument, and Drummer tracks. Use tracks for recording, editing, and arranging regions.
Create a new track with the same configuration as the selected track. Option-click to create a new track that uses the same channel strip.
An editable object representing recorded or imported audio. Drag the middle to move, the lower edges to resize, and the upper-right edge to loop. Use the tools to perform other edits.
A container for note and controller events. Drag the middle to move, the lower edges to resize, and the upper-right edge to loop. Use the tools to perform other edits.
A container for regions. Use for large projects and to create multiple song structures. Double-click the folder region to open it. Click the Display Level button to close it.
The primary area for recording, editing, and arranging audio, MIDI, and Drummer regions, divided into different track types.
Shows an area where you can play and write automation curves, by editing channel strip, Smart Control, and plug-in parameters.
Resize audio waveforms. Click-hold, then drag, to set a zoom level. Click repeatedly to switch between the default and zoomed levels.
Use to select and edit parts of one or more regions. Drag the bar to move the range. Drag the edges to edit the length.
Drag within the area to select parts of one or more regions.
Drag to edit the start point of the marquee selection.
Drag to edit the end point of the marquee selection.
Snap edits to the nearest bar, beat, sub-beat, and so on. The snap operation depends on the ruler division value and the current zoom level.
Snap edits to the nearest bar.
Snap edits to the nearest beat in a bar.
Snap edits to the nearest division value.
Snap edits to the nearest clock tick.
Snap edits to the nearest SMPTE frame.
Snap edits to the nearest SMPTE quarter frame.
Snap edits to the nearest sample.
Snap edits to an absolute and not a relative position. Works in conjunction with the chosen snap setting.
Snap automation, both track- and region-based, to grid positions.
Offset your automation when Snap Automation is selected. You edit the Snap Offset value in Automation preferences.
Use this default setting when you want to drag one region over another, while preserving the original region borders.
Snap take folder comping edits according to the chosen snap setting.
Use when you don't want regions to overlap. The first region—positioned earlier on the track—is reduced in length so that no overlap occurs.
Use to crossfade two overlapping audio regions.
Use to align regions to the right when you move, resize, or delete them.
Use to align regions to the left when you move, resize, or delete them.
Indicates a significant point, or peak, in an audio file.
Use to change the timing of audio material. Drag a flex marker to compress or expand the area on either side of it.
Indicates where audio has been time-stretched during the audio quantization process. Drag a quantize flex marker to convert it to a normal flex marker.
Indicates a tempo change in an audio region, which is maintained during time stretching. When located at the end of an audio region, the region follows the project tempo.
A container for multiple takes. Double-click to show or hide the contents.
Represents one or more take performances.
Switch the take folder's editing mode.
Access takes and comps, and take folder editing commands.
Show or hide track Automation buttons. Use automation to play and write automation curves, by editing channel strip, Smart Control, and plug-in settings.
Show or hide flex editing controls on audio track headers. Use flex to alter the timing and pitch of single notes or entire audio regions.
A realistic drum performance that you can edit using important settings in the Drummer Editor. Control-click and convert to a MIDI region to edit in the Piano Roll Editor.
Snap edits to a relative and not an absolute position. Works in conjunction with the chosen snap setting.
Represents the looped area of an audio region.
Represents the looped area of a MIDI region.
Represents the looped area of a Drummer region.
Represents the looped area of a take folder.
Represents the looped area of a folder region.
Increase the vertical zoom of all tracks. Click again to reset the zoom.
Turn Snap to Grid on or off.
Use to snap edits you make in the Audio Track Editor to zero crossings. This helps ensure that no “click” or other noise is produced at the edit position.
Use to position regions and other items in the Tracks area. Alignment guides appear when the edges of a region you are moving align with another region in the timeline.
Toggle the solo state of soloed tracks in the Tracks area.
Shows the audio regions of the selected track on a time grid. You can edit regions by moving, resizing, trimming, splitting, and joining them.
Choose algorithms that alter the timing and pitch of audio on the track. Use the Region inspector's Flex checkbox to edit regions individually.
Turn flex on or off for the track. When turned on, you can choose to work with Flex Pitch or Flex Time using the pop-up menu that appears on the right.
Choose the value you want to use to correct the timing of audio, or click the Quantize button to use the current value.
Correct the timing of selected audio, using the current value in the Time Quantize pop-up menu.
Limit the tuning adjustment to a particular scale and key, using the right and left pop-up menus respectively.
Set the amount of tuning adjustment.
Click a key to select all notes of that pitch.
Use to edit audio files and regions. Resize an audio region by dragging the waveform's lower-right or left edge.
Play the selected file. Click a second time to stop playback.
Loop playback of the selected file. Use in combination with the Play button.
Shows the original tempo of audio files.
Shows the location of the selected file.
Shows audio files by name. Click a disclosure triangle to display an overview of regions derived from the audio file.
Indicates timestamped or missing files, files that follow the project tempo, or files that contain tempo information.
Shows sample rate, bit depth, input format, and file size. Drag the anchor under the region overview to edit the absolute start point of the audio file.
Use to find files, then drag them into the Tracks area to add them to your project. You can also import data and settings from other projects.
Show folders and files in list format, along with details such as name and date. Double-click a folder to see its contents.
Show folders and contents in column format. Select a folder to see its contents.
Show the contents of the local hard disk, optical drive, or other connected storage media.
Show the contents of your home directory.
Show the contents of the current project folder.
Move through previously viewed levels of the file path.
Move through previously viewed levels of the file path.
Shows the location of the selected folder or file. Navigate by clicking, or use the Back and Forward buttons.
Search for files by name. Click the magnifying glass to view recent searches or to clear the search history. Use the Plus button (+) for detailed searches.
Filter your search by file type, format, length, or other criteria.
Add up to 10 different search filters per project.
Hide search filters. Any existing search filters remain intact and can be shown by clicking the Show Search Filter button.
Add files to the Project Audio Browser, convert ReCycle files to Apple Loops, create a folder, and preview projects in the Finder or with Quick Look.
Play the selected file. Click a second time to stop playback.
Add the file to the selected track, at the playhead position.
Show the contents of the selected folder or open the selected project file.
Import data from the selected project file into your project.
Import settings from the selected project file into your project—screensets, score sets, and record settings, for example.
Replace the data of the selected track in the Tracks area with the selected data from the other project.
Filter the display of data in the view below.
Select the data that you want to import into your project.
Show a hidden search filter below the search field, which you can use to narrow your search according to a number of criteria.
Shows folders and files in the selected location, or that match the search criteria.
Add the selected data to your project. The tracks are added below the selected track in the Tracks area.
Move up the display hierarchy—exiting a folder to the contents of the Tracks area, for example. You can also double-click the workspace.
Click to show all region content, the content of the selected region only, or to unlink the Score Editor display from other workspaces.
Keep the playhead visible as the project plays. The visible section of a window follows the playhead during playback or recording.
Add notes without recording in real time—using your MIDI keyboard, for example.
Play MIDI events when they're clicked, selected, or added.
Shows time divisions, in bars and beats or in hours, minutes, and seconds. Use for playback and recording functions.
Use to repeatedly play or record over the project section within the yellow bar. Drag the bar to move the range, or the edges to edit the length.
Drag to edit the start point of the cycle area.
Drag to edit the end point of the cycle area.
Use to skip the project section within the striped bar. Drag the bar to move the range, or the edges to edit the length.
Use to record over the project section within the red bar. Drag the bar to move the range, or the edges to edit the length.
Drag to edit the start point of the autopunch area.
Drag to edit the end point of the autopunch area.
Indicates the project end point. When recording, the marker moves to fit the project length.
Indicates the playback position. Move by dragging, clicking the lower part of the ruler, or using the LCD Position displays.
Adjust the vertical zoom of the workspace.
Adjust the horizontal zoom of the workspace.
Open the MIDI Draw area, where you can create and edit MIDI controller information.
Use this area to create and edit MIDI controller information.
Indicates the project start point. Drag left to play upbeats or program change commands before the first downbeat.
Assign the next available MIDI controller.
Shows device settings for the selected control surface, some of which can be edited.
Shows device display, send, and plug-in settings for the selected control surfaces group, some of which can be edited.
Modify the drummer's playing style by choosing presets and adjusting individual settings, including kit piece pattern variations and fill settings.
Choose a genre to reveal a selection of drummers, each with a distinct playing style.
Choose a drummer. Each drummer comes with a distinct playing style and drum kit.
Open Drum Kit Designer with the patch associated with the drummer. Use to build custom drum kits and to alter the sound characteristics for each kit piece.
Choose presets that alter the drummer's playing style.
Adjust the sound of selected regions. Drag the puck to the right to make the sound more complex. Drag it upward to play the sound louder.
Click the Toms, Cymbals, or Hi-Hat to play the respective drum pattern. Deselect them to mute. You can also choose whether to include patterns for the Kick and Snare drums.
Include tambourine, shaker, or handclap sounds in the drum performance.
Choose different variations for drum and percussion sounds. You can also choose half or double time variations for the kick and snare drums.
Drag downward to reduce, or upward to increase, the number and length of fills. Click the lock to prevent any changes to the fills setting when switching presets or drummers.
Adjust the shuffle feel of the currently playing pattern. Click the lock to prevent any changes to the swing setting when switching presets or drummers.
Show or hide additional performance settings.
Drag to the right to have the drummer play ahead of the beat or to the left to play behind the beat, or sloppy.
Adjust the level of ghost notes—syncopated snare and kick hits—in the beat. The presence of ghost notes depends on the chosen drummer and the complexity setting.
Adjust the degree to which the Hi-Hat is opened and closed during the drum performance.
Play one or more selected Drummer regions.
Have the selected Drummer region follow the rhythm of the track selected in the Follow Track pop-up menu.
Choose a track whose content will rhythmically influence the Kick and Snare portions of the selected Drummer region.
Reflects the time position of the selected Drummer region in bars and beats.
Return to the overview and choose a different drummer.
Return to the overview and choose a different genre.
Influenced by modern rock, but comfortable with most genres, Kyle plays straightforward rock beats on a natural, versatile kit.
Inspired by legendary drum heroes of the past, Logan plays sparse, hard-hitting rock beats and fills on a retro-sounding kit.
Influenced by heavy, riffing rock bands, Anders plays grinding beats on a massive-sounding kit.
Hailing from Berkeley, Max is influenced by fast, hyperactive punk rock. He plays tight, energetic beats on a punchy kit.
Inspired by hard rock bands and funk pioneers, Jesse plays in-your-face beats on a tight-sounding kit.
Drawing influences from psychedelic rock and modern pop, Ian plays grooving, intricate beats on a big, arena kit.
Inspired by a love of disco and years as a DJ, Nikki plays bouncy, rock-infused dance beats on a processed, hard-hitting kit.
Although an exceptional drummer, Aidan insists on restraint and plays intentionally simple, indie rock beats on a natural kit.
Although worried that his music school training will ruin his street cred, Gavin plays complex indie rock beats on a gritty-sounding kit.
Zak's spirited, explosive style is influenced by stripped-down, no-nonsense rock. He plays driving beats on a raw-sounding kit.
Tasteful, restrained, and dedicated to serving the song, Darcy plays simple, tasteful pop beats on a natural-sounding kit.
Inspired by Americana and classic R&B artists, Mason plays loose, swaggering beats on a vintage kit.
Influenced by British Invasion artists, Parker plays classic rock beats and bombastic tom fills on a muted, vintage kit.
Experimental and virtuosic, Graham combines multiple influences to create genre-bending beats on a processed-sounding kit.
Inspired by laid-back, sun-soaked modern pop, Levi plays funky pop beats on a natural-sounding kit.
Benny's style pays homage to classic Motown. He plays tight, funky beats with minimal fills on a vintage kit.
Influenced by new soul and classic R&B, Rose plays laid-back, cross-stick-driven grooves on a dry, natural kit.
Using his jazz skills to put a twist on modern R&B and hip-hop, Curtis plays tight beats and unique fills on a hard-hitting kit.
Choose whether the swing is based on eighth notes or sixteenth notes.
Click the Hi-Hat or Cymbals to play the respective drum pattern. Deselect them to mute.
Click the Kick or Snare drums, or handclaps, to play the respective drum pattern. Deselect them to mute.
Use to offset the complexity of individual kit pieces against the XY pad. Click the icon to mute this setting.
Have Drummer regions generated in half time, if the project tempo is a multiple of the preferred tempo.
Use to generate drum patterns that are not perfectly quantized, making the performance more realistic, or human.
Use to determine the amount of rhythmic change that occurs over the course of several bars within a region.
Open Drum Machine Designer with the patch associated with the drummer. Use to build custom electronic drum kits and to alter the sound characteristics for each kit piece.
Maya’s signature sound is a flashback to the ‘80s. She uses vintage drum machines to create retro-sounding, reverb-soaked beats.
Duncan layers acoustic and electronic drum samples to create tight, energetic beats that propel electronic pop songs and Top 40 hits.
A popular dance music festival headliner, Magnus creates thunderous electro house beats to compliment anthemic synth leads and bass drops.
Leah embraces a lean, minimal production style to create nuanced, subtly-evolving tech house beats with a tight, synthetic-sounding kit.
Inspired by underground sounds from London and years as a heavy metal drummer, Jasper creates bombastic dubstep beats and explosive fills.
Ronnie blends underground dubstep sounds from his native London with southern hip hop to create earth-shaking, electro-infused trap beats.
Julian combines modern technology with vintage drum machines to create contemporary house beats that pay homage to classic club tracks.
Drawing inspiration from southern hip hop, Dez creates raw-sounding trap beats featuring trunk-rattling kicks and rapid-fire hi-hats.
Rap icon, fashion mogul, and producer Anton creates polished, modern hip hop beats with mainstream commercial appeal.
Maurice is a hip hop purist, creating chopped-up, boom bap drum beats out of sampled breaks from classic funk and soul vinyl records.
Lists all events in a selected MIDI region. You can filter the list to one or more event types, simplifying the selection and editing process.
Add an event, based on the event type chosen in the pop-up menu.
Show or hide note events. Use to play software instruments and external MIDI sound modules or keyboards.
Choose the note value you want to use to correct the timing of selected note events, or click the Quantize button to apply the current value.
Correct the timing of selected note events, using the current value in the Quantize pop-up menu.
Drag values vertically to edit event or region information, or double-click and enter a new value.
Show or hide program change events. Use for patch selection, by transmitting them to connected MIDI devices.
Show or hide pitch bend events, generated by a pitch bend wheel on your keyboard. Use to vary the pitch.
Show or hide control change events. Use to transfer MIDI controller data to software instruments or external MIDI keyboards and modules.
Show or hide aftertouch events, generated by a mechanical pressure sensor on musical keyboards. Use to modulate the sound.
Show or hide polyphonic pressure events, generated by a mechanical pressure sensor on musical keyboards. Use to modulate the sound.
Show or hide system exclusive events.
Show or hide all information that is stored with the event or region, such as the release velocity of a note event.
Click to show or hide specific event types.
Choose the event type to be added when you click the Add Event button.
Work with global tracks to control various aspects of the overall project, such as arrangement and tempo.
Contains markers, which are used to label bar positions and parts of the project.
Add a marker at the playhead position.
Add a marker at the start point of each selected region. You can also drag a region onto the Marker track.
View, create, delete, and rename marker sets. You can have up to nine variations in a project.
Shows movie frames as thumbnails that are synchronized with the ruler. Cuts in the movie can be detected and marked.
Remove the movie from the project.
Search the entire movie for scene cuts. Detected scene cuts are saved to a marker set in the Marker track.
Contains the basic time and key signatures of the project, along with signature changes.
View, create, delete, and rename signature sets. You can have up to nine variations in a project.
Contains transposition events used to transpose parts of a project up or down in pitch.
Contains all tempo changes in the project.
Adjust the number of tempo change events shown on the tempo curve.
View, create, delete, and rename tempo sets. You can have up to nine variations in a project.
Move tempo change events to the nearest quantize grid position, ensuring that tempo changes align with significant note events.
Use to adjust the tempo to follow recordings that do not follow a strict tempo, without changing rhythmic feel of the recordings.
Analyze selected audio regions for significant peaks, or transients. You can also drag a region onto the Beat Mapping track.
Edit the transient detection threshold across selected regions.
Edit the transient detection threshold across selected regions.
Open a dialog where you can trigger an automatic beat-mapping process on a selected region.
Keep existing MIDI events at their current ruler position during beat mapping.
Browse for a movie file, which opens in the Movie window.
Contains arrangement markers, which you can use to quickly reorganize a project.
Adjust the range of the tempo track. Drag the maximum and minimum values vertically to edit them, or double-click and enter a new value.
Add an arrangement marker—which is eight bars long, by default.
Search the movie section within the cycle area for scene cuts. Detected scene cuts are saved to a marker set in the Marker track.
Add Scene Cuts to Marker Set
Add a time signature change at the playhead position.
Work with the Marker track only. Use markers to label bar positions and parts of the project.
Open a window that lists the movie name, location, format, duration, frame rate, size, and data rate.
Import the chapter markers from the movie and create a marker set.
Select to turn on all channel strip groups. When unselected, you can make changes to individual channel strips outside of the group.
Specifies the channel strip group number.
Select to turn on this channel strip group. When unselected, you can make changes to individual channel strips outside of this group.
Double-click to rename the channel strip group.
Hide all channel strips in the group.
When selected, selecting a region selects the same horizontal range of all group members.
Define whether a channel strip group is phase locked or independent when quantizing audio.
Match the automation mode for all channel strips in the selected group.
Adjust the volume of all channel strips in the selected group. The channel strips maintain their relative volume levels.
Match the mute state of all channel strips in the selected group.
Match the input monitoring state of all channel strips in the selected group.
Edit the pan positions of all channel strips in the selected group. The channel strips maintain their relative pan positions.
Match the solo state of all channel strips in the selected group.
Match the record-enable state of all channel strips in the selected group.
Edit the send level of all channel strips in the selected group.
Match the color of all channel strips in the selected group.
Match the zoom of all tracks in the selected channel strip group.
Hide all tracks in the selected channel strip group.
Shows notes and controller events in a MIDI region. You can add and edit note velocities, or quickly create and edit MIDI drum parts.
Shows the real-time velocity and position of the pointer as you navigate the workspace.
Each MIDI event type, be it a note or MIDI controller, is arranged from top to bottom in horizontal lanes much like the track lanes shown in the Tracks area.
Each beam, called a step, represents a MIDI event.
You can save groups of lanes (several lanes that you have defined) as Lane Sets. You access these from the Lane Set pop-up menu in the inspector.
Use to alter the settings of the selected lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Edit settings for the selected MIDI event type, or lane.
Move the pointer over an item to show its name and function. To hide or show Quick Help, choose Help > Quick Help or use the key command.
Shows a QuickTime movie. Double-click to view it in a separate window, or open the global Movie track to view the movie in single frames.
Use these settings to determine the playback behavior of one or more selected regions.
Use these settings to determine the playback behavior of the selected track.
Use to control the signal of the selected track without having to open the Mixer.
Use to control the signal output of the left channel strip, using an output, aux, or the master channel strip.
Load and save channel strip settings, which contain setup information for a channel strip, including plug-ins.
Double-click to add a Channel EQ, or to open an inserted Channel or Linear Phase EQ. Use EQ to shape an audio signal by adjusting the levels of specific frequency ranges.
Insert an audio effect. Click an occupied slot to open the plug-in. Use effects to alter signals in real time.
Route the signal to an aux channel strip. Use sends to process or submix multiple track output signals.
Drag to control the amount of signal sent to an aux channel strip. Use sends to process or submix multiple track output signals.
Choose the channel strip input source—the physical input that your microphone or instrument is connected to.
Insert an instrument plug-in. Click an occupied slot to open the plug-in. You can play or record instruments in real time using Musical Typing.
Click-hold to choose the channel strip output destination—where the channel strip signal is sent.
Add the channel strip to a group. You can also define which channel strip controls can be edited for the entire group at the same time.
Set how channel strip and plug-in changes are handled during recording and playback.
Shows the signal peak during playback. A red display on output channel strips indicates signal clipping. To fix, reduce the Volume fader by the value shown.
Drag vertically to position the channel strip signal in the stereo field.
Shows the signal output during playback. Watch the level meter and the peak level display during playback or recording to see if signal clipping occurs.
Set a track's playback volume. Use on an aux or output channel strip to adjust the volume of that part of the mix, or on the master channel strip to set the overall project volume.

Silence a track's signal, audibly removing it from the overall composition. Use on an aux or output channel strip to silence that part of the mix, or on the master channel strip to mute the overall project.
Isolate a track's signal from the overall composition so that it can be heard alone. Use on an aux or output channel strip to isolate that part of the mix.
Hear incoming signals on audio tracks that are not record-enabled. This is useful when setting levels or practicing parts before recording.
Switch the channel strip input format between Mono and Stereo. Click-hold to choose Left, Right, or Surround format.
Render the signal of one or more output channel strips to an audio file, or to multiple audio files.
Double-click to rename the channel strip.
Choose a quantize grid format, used to correct the timing of notes in the selected region.
Delay the position of every other note in the quantize grid to achieve a swing or shuffle groove.
Adjust the pitch of notes by the chosen value.
Move the playback position of all region types.
Adjust the note on velocity of all MIDI note events by the chosen value.
Adjust the volume of audio regions by the chosen value.
Increase or decrease the differences between soft and loud MIDI note events.
Switch between Fade In and Speed Up parameters, where you apply fade values for volume and playback. Double-click to the right and enter a value.
Adjust the length of MIDI note events.
Adjust the shape of the fade-in or fade-out curve.
Adjust the length of MIDI regions to alter the length of the last notes in the region.
Switch between Fade Out and Slow Down parameters, where you apply fade values for volume and playback. Double-click to the right and enter a value.
Prevent the score display of some MIDI regions—those that only contain MIDI events that can't be displayed in the score.
Have Apple Loops follow the project tempo.
Turn flex on or off for individual audio regions.
Determine how far a note is shifted toward the nearest quantize grid position.
Retain the original feel of the material while positioning the rhythmic center precisely in the groove.
Spread out notes—chords, for example—that have the same time position.
Determine the amount by which the velocity values of a template MIDI region affect the velocity values of quantized notes.
Determine how the lengths of quantized notes are affected by the equivalent note lengths of a template MIDI region.
Choose an icon for the track.
Shows the channel strip type and number for the track.
Choose the MIDI channel for the track output.
Choose Source Only to freeze the track signal without effect plug-ins, or Pre Fader to freeze the track with all effect plug-ins.
Select to have all regions on the track contribute their transients as reference points during quantization.
Transpose all note events on the track in octaves.
Adjust the velocity for notes in all regions on the track.
Use the two values to define the key range. Any notes with a key outside this range are not played.
Use the two values to define the velocity range. Any notes with a velocity outside this range are not played.
Set the instrument delay in ticks or in milliseconds.
Protect all MIDI regions on tracks that reference this channel strip from being transposed when selected.
Prevent reset messages from being sent to the channel strip.
Choose the default staff style for the track, or open the Staff Style window.
Choose the physical MIDI output that data is sent to.
Select the checkbox to send program change information. Choose the program change setting from the pop-up menu.
Select the checkbox to send volume controller information.
Select the checkbox to send pan controller information.
Choose a Flex mode to alter the timing and pitch of audio on the track.
Turn the decay function on or off. Any gaps that occur between sounds as a result of shifting the audio are filled.
Set the decay time between sounds, because no time stretching takes place to compensate for the gaps.
Shorten each slice by a percentage value. Useful for removing unwanted pre-attack sounds from the following slice, or to create a gated effect.
Set the length of the looped section at the end of a slice that is used for time expansion.
Define a decay value for the looped area.
Move the looped area up to 100 ms to the left. Prevents pre-attack sounds from the following transient to appear in the looped and crossfaded area.
Preserve the area around transient markers to protect the percussive part of the sound.
Enable more internal transients in the audio material.
Set the size of the grains that are played or repeated in their original speed and crossfaded to create time compression or expansion.
Adjust the crossfade length from 0.00 (produces hard artifacts) to the full grain length of 1.00 (tends to sound softer).
Show or hide the EQ display on selected channel strips.
Show or hide the Effect slots on selected channel strips.
Show or hide the Send slots on selected channel strips.
Show or hide the Input and Output slots on selected channel strips.
Prevent the selected track from following the Hermode Tuning scale. Ideal for a drum kit that you don’t want tuned like your melodic software instrument parts.
Set the surround position of the channel strip signal. Double-click to open the Surround Panner window.
Insert a MIDI effect. Double-click an occupied slot to open the plug-in.
Use these options to define which controls can be edited for the entire channel strip group at the same time.
Choose between four different fade types.
Click to choose a sound by name from the pop-up menu.
Choose a bank number for the channel strip.
Assign to a MIDI controller, used to remotely control parameters such as volume, pan, and chorus on an external MIDI instrument.
Determine the interval at which formants are tracked along the signal.
Determine how formants adjust to pitch shifts. When set to 0, formants are adjusted together with pitch shifts.
Choose, create, delete, and rename Environment layers, which help to keep the Environment organized.
Make the object available to tracks in the Tracks area. Assign to a track by control-clicking the track's header and choosing the object.
Set the binaural pan position of the channel strip signal. Double-click to open the Binaural Panner window.
Choose a bank number for the channel strip, if your MIDI device supports bank select events.
Shows the playback volume. Use the Volume fader to set the playback volume of the track's signal.
Click to view Library content for the highlighted slot. You can also use it to open or close the Library.
Determine the playback speed of selected regions.
Choose a quantize grid format, used to correct the timing of notes in the selected region.
Determine whether regions play forward or reverse.
Load and save patches, plug-in presets, or EXS instruments, based on the selected channel strip slot. Loading a patch can affect multiple channel strips.
Choose a category to reveal patches.
Load to the selected channel strip. You can start playing it immediately.
Search for patches and presets by name. Click the magnifying glass to view recent searches or to clear the search history.
Access patch merging and user default commands.
Revert to the saved settings for the patch or plug-in preset. As this will erase any changes you made, save with a different name before reverting.
Choose a category to reveal plug-in presets.
Choose a category to reveal EXS instruments.
Choose a MIDI device to reveal the available MIDI channels.
Assign to the selected channel strip.
Double-click to use ReWire instruments on external MIDI channel strips.
Assign to the selected channel strip.
Save the patch or plug-in preset with its current settings as a new patch or plug-in preset.
Delete the selected patch or plug-in preset. This action can't be undone.
Shows patches or plug-in presets with names that contain the search text.
Use to refresh your local library.
Open an area where you can choose the patch settings that you want to import from another patch to the current patch.
Use to define default user patches.
Use to clear default user patches.
Choose the patch settings that you want to import from another patch to the current patch.
To download the dimmed patches, choose Logic Pro > Download Additional Content.
Shows audio and software instrument loops. Browse or search for loops, then preview them before dragging a loop into the Tracks area.
Browse for loops by navigating the keyword columns from left to right. When you find a loop you like, drag it into the Tracks area.
Browse for loops by clicking one or more keyword buttons. When you find a loop you like, drag it into the Tracks area.
Filter loops by clicking one or more buttons. When you find a loop you like, drag it into the Tracks area.
Represents a MIDI performance. Use as a MIDI region on software instrument tracks or as an audio region on audio tracks.
Represents an original audio recording. Use as an audio region on audio tracks.
Show loops whose Favorites checkbox is selected.
Mark a loop as a favorite. Click the Favorites button to show your favorite loops.
Choose which loops to display. You can display all available loops, or filter loops by Jam Pack or the user’s loop library.
Show loops based on the scale you choose.
Show loops based on the time signature you choose.
Play loops in their original key, the project key, or any key from C to B.
Sort loops by key. Use the “Play in” pop-up menu to play loops in their original key, the project key, or any key from C to B.
Sort loops by the number of beats in the bar.
Display loops as a percentage match between the project tempo and the original loop tempo.
Filter loops by navigating the keyword columns from left to right. When you find a loop you like, drag it into the Tracks area.
Show loops based on the library you choose.
Sort loops according to Favorites checkbox selection.
Show loops that are part of the same loop family. You can quickly try out different loops in the same family to see which one you like best.
Use to find and import songs from your iTunes library and movies from your Movies folder. You can also import GarageBand projects.
Import songs from your iTunes library and GarageBand projects into your project.
Import movies from your Movies folder and iMovie projects into your project.
Show the signal flow of the channel strip that corresponds to the selected track in the Tracks area.
Show the signal flow of all channel strips that correspond to tracks in the Tracks area.
Show the signal flow of all channel strips in the project.
Show or hide audio channel strips, which you use to control the playback and recording of audio signals on audio tracks.
Show or hide instrument channel strips, which you use to control software instruments, driven by a recorded MIDI region or by playing your MIDI keyboard.
Show or hide auxiliary (aux) channel strips, which you use to process effects for multiple signals at the same time.
Show or hide bus channel strips. Included for compatibility with earlier versions of Logic.
Show or hide input channel strips. Included for compatibility with earlier versions of Logic.
Show or hide output channel strips, which you use to adjust the overall volume and balance of audio, instrument, and aux channel strips routed to them.
Show or hide the master channel strip, which you use as a global control for all output channel strips.
Show or hide external MIDI channel strips, which you use to control MIDI instruments on external MIDI tracks.
Double-click to add or edit track notes. You can also do this in the Track Note Pad.
Add aux channel strips to the right of this channel strip. Use to process sounds in a drum kit with different effects, for example.
Remove aux channel strips that are linked to this multi-output instrument channel strip.
Set the volume according to the Dim value set in General audio preferences. Otherwise, the volume follows the master Volume fader.
Shows the gain reduction of the first Compressor or Silver Compressor plug-in. If neither is inserted, it shows the gain reduction of an inserted Limiter or Adaptive Limiter plug-in.
Reduce the width of channel strips in the Mixer.
Increase the width of channel strips in the Mixer.
Show or hide subtracks. Make sure that View > Follow Track Stacks is chosen from the Mixer menu bar.
Use to control the volume, or automate a submix, of tracks that are assigned to the VCA Fader.
Lists all markers in the project. Use markers for selection, playback, editing, and arrangement tasks.
Add a marker at the playhead position.
Show or hide the Marker Text area, where you can view, add, or edit text for the selected marker.
Use to add or edit text for the selected marker. You can also double-click the Marker Text area.
Double-click to add or edit text for the selected marker. You can also click the Marker Text Edit button.
View, create, delete, and rename marker sets. You can have up to nine variations in a project.
Change the font, style, color, and size of selected text in the Marker Text area.
Drag position and length values vertically to edit them, or double-click and enter a new value.
Use to view, create, or edit a single set of notes for the project.
Double-click to add or edit project notes. You can also click the Project Text Edit button.
Use to add or edit project notes. You can also double-click the Project Text area.
Use to view, create, or edit notes for the selected track. You can also do this in the Mixer.
Double-click to add or edit track notes. You can also click the Track Text Edit button.
Use to add or edit track notes. You can also double-click the Track Text area.
Change the font, style, color, and size of selected text in the Project Text area.
Change the font, style, color, and size of selected text in the Track Text area.
These preferences provide access to a number of advanced features and additional options.
Determines a default time value for all crossfade operations in the Tracks area.
Determines a global curve type for all crossfade operations in the Tracks area.
Sets the maximum scrubbing speed. You can choose between normal and double playback speed.
Sets the reaction time for audio scrubbing. Your choices are Slow, Normal, Fast, and Faster.
Provides a warning before carrying out a destructive edit in the Audio File Editor when you use a key command.
Deletes the Undo History automatically when you close the project.
Select if you want to be able to undo and redo selection changes in the Audio File Editor.
Select if you want to be able to undo and redo Normalize function changes in the Audio File Editor.
Determines the maximum number of undo steps that are retained.
Lets you choose an external application for sample editing tasks.
When selected, displays an alert message in an overload situation. Otherwise, playback will simply stop without displaying an alert.
Display Audio Engine Overload Message checkbox
Determines which parameters, if any, are automated with sample accuracy. This type of automation is very processor intensive.
Determines the file type for recorded audio.
When selected, Logic Pro can record 24-bit files.
Turns software monitoring on or off. In most situations, you should leave it on (default).
Turns software monitoring on or off for the focused track in the Tracks area. This is on by default.
Allows the use of an independent monitoring level for record-enabled audio channel strips. This is off by default.
Sets a discrete level for the Dim function. You can set a dim level from 0 dB to –30 dB.
Compensates for audio delays that can be introduced when using plug-ins.
You need to select the Low Latency Mode checkbox in order to turn on Low Latency mode and use the Limit slider.
Determines what happens to automation data when you move regions.
Includes the automation trails of regions (automation parameter movements in the empty space that follows a region) with all Copy or Move actions.
Allows a specific number of ticks to be added to, or subtracted from, the current snapped position of all automation data (as set in the Snap pop-up menu in the Tracks area).
Determines the time required by a parameter to return to its previously recorded setting.
Determines the mode that faders automatically switch to once automation data recording has been completed.
Write Mode Changes to pop-up menu
Determine the types of automation data that can be written in Touch, Latch, and Write modes.
Allow you to use a single hardware controller to automate the currently active automation parameter of the selected track.
Turns on Catch mode whenever you click Play or Pause.
Turns on Catch mode whenever you move the playhead.
If the Catch button is turned on and Content Link is selected in the local View menu, the contents of the region at the current playhead position are shown.
Catch Content by Playhead Position checkbox
These preferences affect the onscreen appearance and performance of control surfaces.
These preferences affect the onscreen appearance and performance of control surfaces.
Processes a cycle jump slightly before its actual position, in order to ensure a smooth cycle jump from the end point to the start point of the cycle.
Improves the timing of cycle jumps, making it easier to set the length of sample loops while in Cycle mode.
Use to choose between any installed Core Audio device, including the internal sound hardware.
Use to choose between any installed Core Audio device, including the internal sound hardware.
Determines the size of the buffer used by the audio hardware for both input and output.
Displays the resulting roundtrip and output latency for the I/O buffer size.
Delays the recording of audio by a certain fixed value, helping you to compensate for any delays that are caused by the audio driver.
Determines the size of the buffer used to compute mixes and effects.
Configures the ReWire behavior when sending MIDI data to a ReWire-compatible software instrument.
Switches between a dark and light background in the Piano Roll Editor.
When selected, local menu items are displayed in a larger font.
When selected, inspector settings are displayed in a larger font.
When selected, a thicker playhead is used in all windows.
When selected, help tags appear throughout Logic Pro when you move the pointer over interface elements and tools.
When selected, default parameter values are displayed in help tags. This makes it easier to determine the amount of variance from the default value.
When selected, an icon-style New Tracks dialog is shown. Otherwise, a text-style New Tracks dialog is displayed.
Show Icons in New Tracks Dialog checkbox
Affects the description of notes in the editors. The bottom C on a five-octave keyboard (note # 36) is labeled C1, and middle C (note # 60) is labeled C3.
Display Middle C as pop-up menu
Use to customize the Time display in the control bar.
Use to customize the Tempo display in the control bar
Use to customize the Beats display in the control bar.
Opens the window of a plug-in automatically after it is inserted in the channel strip.
Switches level meters between an Exponential scale and a Sectional dB-linear scale.
Determines the order of channels in multichannel (surround) level meters.
When selected, looped sections of regions in the Tracks area are shown in a shaded color. Otherwise, they reflect the full color of the original region.
Determines the number of undo steps.
When selected, adds a description of the edit operation (cutting, for example) to the name of the region, or resulting regions.
Editing an original region also alters any quantization template derived from that region.
Determines how Logic Pro handles the cutting of looped regions.
Selecting a track selects all regions on the track lane, or regions within the cycle or autopunch area (if Cycle or Autopunch mode is on).
Determines whether the right mouse button opens the Tool menu, displays an additional Right-click Tool menu, or opens a shortcut menu.
Placing the pointer over the upper-left and upper-right edges of a region activates the Fade pointer.
Placing the pointer over the lower half of a region (with the exception of the lower-left and lower-right edges) activates the Marquee pointer.
When selected, you can only move notes in one direction when editing in the Piano Roll or Score Editor.
When selected, you can only move regions (including folders) in one direction in the Tracks area.
Determines which editor opens when you double-click a MIDI region in the Tracks area.
Audio Output preferences let you set the physical output pair on which the stereo output is played, and the surround format.
Audio Bounce Extensions preferences let you set the bounce extension and the surround format.
These preferences let you set the surround format.
If using external synchronization and the timecode stops while recording, record mode is turned off.
External Stop Message Ends Recording checkbox
Resets all MIDI drivers. This can help if you experience MIDI communication problems.
Fine-tunes the start point of a movie.
Defines the resolution of the thumbnails kept in the temporary internal memory (cache).
Defines the amount of memory reserved for the thumbnail cache.
When selected, the Movie window stays in its current user-defined position, and playback continues, when changing screensets.
You can choose bit rates between 32 kbps and 320 kbps. The defaults are 80 kbps mono and 160 kbps stereo.
Variable Bit Rate (VBR) encoding compresses simpler passages more heavily than harmonically rich passages, generally resulting in better-quality MP3s.
Keep this set to Highest whenever possible. Reducing the quality accelerates the conversion process, but at the expense of audio quality.
If you deselect this option, you will gain encoding speed at the price of audio quality. Keep selected, unless conversion time is an issue.
Frequencies below 10 Hz are removed, leaving slightly more data bandwidth for the frequencies that humans can hear, resulting in an improvement in perceived quality.
Choose between Joint Stereo and Normal Stereo.
The My Info pane contains song sharing preferences, which Logic Pro uses to identify your songs when sharing them via iTunes or SoundCloud, for example.
Resets all warnings and alerts that were previously set to “Do not show again.”
Defines what happens when Logic Pro is opened.
Allows you to choose a default template when Create New Project using Default Template is chosen from the Startup Action pop-up menu.
If selected and you open a new project before closing the old one, a dialog asks whether or not the current project should be closed.
If only one MIDI region is selected when you choose File > Export > Selection as MIDI File, the contents of the region are saved in MIDI file format 0.
Defines the number of alternatives that are saved as part of the project.
These preferences are included for compatibility with older MIDI hardware. For selected controller types, a reset message will be sent to all MIDI outputs.
Displays the staff lines of the currently selected MIDI region in color. All other regions are displayed with black staff lines.
Displays units in the Page Score view ruler in inches. If not selected, the unit defaults to centimeters.
Display Distance Values in Inches checkbox
Determines the window that opens when you double-click a note head: Note Attributes, Event List, Piano Roll, or Step Editor.
Choose the color of selected objects in the Score Editor. Click the Reset button to revert to the default color.
Choose from any installed scoring (symbol) fonts, such as the Sonata font.
Choose either the Clipboard or a PDF File as the destination for image exports with the Camera tool.
Saves newly recorded notes automatically with the different MIDI channels used in the corresponding staff style.
Delays or advances the MIDI output for all ports, so you can compensate for any timing differences between MIDI tracks and audio or software instrument tracks.
Allows Logic Pro to send Song Position Pointer (SPP) data while playing.
This should generally be set to zero, to ensure the quickest possible pickup time while Logic Pro is in MIDI Time Code (MTC) Sync mode.
Delays the transmission of MIDI timecode.
Choose between MMC standard messages and the old Fostex format.
The All checkbox sends MMC to all ports. Use the field to the right to specify an output port ID.
The All checkbox sends MMC to all ports. Use the field to the right to specify an input port ID.
Transmits MMC Locate commands when the Stop button (or Stop key command) is used twice.
Transmits MMC Locate commands with the position of a region that is dragged in the Tracks area when Logic Pro is stopped.
Transmits MMC record-enable and record-disable commands when audio tracks are record-enabled or disabled.
Shows notes in a MIDI region on a time grid. Edit notes by moving or resizing them, or by dragging them up or down to change pitch.
Choose the value you want to use to correct the timing of notes, or click the Quantize button to use the current value.
Correct the timing of selected notes, using the current value in the Time Quantize pop-up menu.
Shows the real-time pitch and position of the pointer as you navigate the workspace.
Define the nearest grid position that notes snap to when you move or resize them.
Click a key to select all notes of that pitch. Drag across a range of keys to select all notes within that pitch range.
Move notes horizontally and vertically to change their time position and pitch, respectively.
Represents a MIDI note or command, which you can edit the same way as regions.
Limit the tuning adjustment to a particular scale and key, using the right and left pop-up menus respectively.
Correct the pitch of selected notes, using the current value in the Scale Quantize pop-up menu.
Change the velocity value of selected notes.
Show only those lanes that are occupied by notes in selected regions.
Represents those lanes that are occupied by notes in selected regions. Turn off or on using the Collapse Mode button.
Represents the best matching display for the Piano Roll Editor.
Shows audio file content as a waveform graphic. Use to edit samples within an audio file.
Analyzes the audio file for transient events, and marks them. You can increase or decrease the number of events detected using the +/– buttons.
Edit the threshold for transient detection across the entire audio file, or a section of it.
Starts and stops playback of the selected file, region, or loop.
Loops playback of the selected area.
Shows the start point and length of the selected area.
Shows a miniature view of the entire audio waveform. Click different parts to focus them in the waveform display underneath.
Shows the position of the region in the project. If you have not yet added the audio file to your song, the position marker lines are dotted, indicating no time connection exists.
Indicates the amplitude of the audio waveform as a percentage or in sample units.
Shows a detailed view of the waveform area selected in the waveform overview.
Indicates the absolute start point of the audio file.
Indicates the length of the region. Edit this beam to adjust the region length.
Drag horizontally to edit the start point of the region marker.
Drag horizontally to edit the end point of the region marker.
Open EXS24 mkII samples in the Audio File Editor and edit their start and end points.
Drag horizontally to edit the start point of the sample loop.
Drag horizontally to edit the end point of the sample loop.
Indicates a significant peak in the audio file. Use transients for audio file selection and editing tasks.
Shows notes in a MIDI region as traditional music notation. You can add or edit notes and other musical symbols.
Apply visual quantization to notes, setting the shortest note value that can be displayed in the selected region.
Produce an easy-to-read score by displaying notes with longer length values than their actual length.
Produce a cleaner-looking score by displaying syncopated notes with fewer ties or subdivisions.
Simplify the display of overlapping notes in melodies played with an exaggerated legato.
Use these settings to determine the display of notation in the score. Does not affect playback of the original regions.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of notes and other items in the score.
Show or hide collections of score symbols. Drag symbols into the Score Editor to add them to your score.
Define the maximum number of dots that can be displayed for single notes.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Choose a staff style for the selected track or region.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Use these settings to determine the appearance and positioning of objects in the score.
Choose a score set, or open the Score Set window where you can create and edit score sets.
Show the score in a continuous, horizontally scrolling view. This is the standard view for editing the score.
Show the score in a lead sheet-style, line-wrapped view.
Show the full score on facing pages. Use this view to work on the score layout and print the full score.
These settings let you select which asset types are copied to the project package—audio files, EXS instruments, and other data, for example.
Makes the creation and management of tracks and channel strips a transparent experience.
Automatic Management of Channel Strips checkbox
Allows the automatic naming of channel strips according to the last loaded setting, until the user enters a channel strip name manually.
Automatic Naming of Channel Strips checkbox
When selected, all start commands force Logic Pro to start playback a little earlier.
Use to choose the sample rate for the project.
Use to choose the surround format for the project.
Signals panned to the center position may sound louder than signals panned hard left or right.
Applies Pan Law compensation to Stereo Balance controls.
Apply Pan Law Compensation to Stereo Balancers checkbox
Sends any notes due to start playing at the playback start point.
Sends any notes that are still playing at the playback start point (due to a sustain pedal event).
Instrument channel strips (particularly drums) can be assigned No Transpose status in the inspector.
In ‘No Transpose’ Instrument Channel Strips checkbox
Sends any program changes in regions that fall across the playback start point.
Sends pitch bend events that immediately precede the playback start point.
Select to search for continuous controllers 0 to 15, continuous switch controllers 64 to 71, or all other controllers.
Transmits the most recent SysEx message before the playback start point.
Transmits the most recent Text Meta Event message before the playback start point.
Scans for events on each MIDI subchannel, rather than the global multi-instrument channel.
Scans for, and sends, all event types if the cycle start and end points fall across regions.
Limits cycle jump scan to note events.
Sends a MIDI reset message before chasing, ensuring that all MIDI devices being triggered are set to their defaults.
Sets the ruler to bars and beats, and tempo information is recorded into audio files. When unselected, the ruler is set to time, and tempo information is not recorded into audio files.
If selected, track-based automation is suspended between the region start and end, if the region contains automation data for the same parameter.
If selected, the parameter value you set in the channel strip or plug-in is applied to all regions that do not have automation data for that parameter.
These settings let you control which event types are filtered.
Defines basic metronome settings for recording and playback.
Turns the metronome on during recording. This is the same as clicking the Metronome button in the control bar.
The metronome is only audible during the project count-in, and is then turned off.
Turns the metronome on during playback. This is the same as clicking the Metronome button in the control bar.
The metronome sends notes, as defined for bars, beats, and divisions. Two or three notes may be sent simultaneously at the beginning of each measure, for example.
Turns the Klopfgeist metronome on or off.
Generates separate note events for bars.
Generates separate note events for beats.
Generates separate note events for divisions.
Defines the note number of generated notes.
Defines the velocity of generated notes.
Defines the MIDI channel of generated notes.
Changes the sound of the virtual metronome from a short click to a pitched percussion sound, similar to a wood block or claves.
Sets the output level of the virtual click sound.
Allows you to route the Klopfgeist metronome sound to a different set of hardware outputs, if the audio hardware used by Logic Pro offers more than two outputs.
Choose a direct MIDI output port (or all ports) for the metronome.
Sends the active instrument MIDI settings automatically after loading a project.
Sends all Environment fader values automatically, once a project is loaded.
Keep unselected to ensure that all MIDI plug-ins and Smart Control mappings work as intended.
Incoming SysEx messages are passed through the computer to the MIDI outputs, along with other MIDI data.
SysEx with MIDI Thru Function checkbox
The instrument selected here will not pass events through the computer when the instrument is assigned to the selected track.
Instrument Without MIDI Thru Function pop-up menu
Moves the position of the full movie to the left or right.
Moves the position of the movie region to the left or right.
Determines the start position of the movie region.
Determines the end position of the movie region.
Shows the length of the movie region, based on the start and end positions.
Sets the volume of the audio track.
Mutes the volume of the audio track.
Synchronizes the movie to a specified tempo, which you set in the Basis Tempo field.
Use to choose between a count-in or pre-roll period when starting to record.
Sets the count-in period that precedes a recording.
Records all tempo changes made while in record mode.
Assigns a take folder the color chosen from the Color palette for the first take recording, but different colors for each of the following takes in that take folder.
Set the behavior when your MIDI or audio recordings overlap.
Switches between layer recording and multiplayer recording, when recording to multiple software instrument tracks.
Controller events are thinned out during recording, to reduce the data load on the MIDI bus during playback.
Allows you to select or create a recording folder outside of the project.
Resets the recording path back to the project.
Global Score settings define global formatting options such as page margins, note spacing, bars per line, and more.
These settings affect the automatic display of page numbers, bar numbers, and instrument names in the score.
Guitar tablature is a method of notating music for fretted string instruments—especially for guitar and electric bass—but also for other fretted instruments, with four to six strings.
These settings define the font, position, and scaling of chords and grids, and other settings.
These settings define the display of clefs and signatures in the score, and other settings.
These settings define the display of staff line thickness, stem length, and distance between notes and ties, or notes and dots, and other settings.
These settings determine if, and to what extent, the insertion of the listed symbols affects the MIDI playback of notes (that these symbols are attached to).
These settings define the pitch, velocity, and note color options.
Shows the deviation between the incoming MTC and its nominal frame rate.
Shows the deviation of the sample rate from its nominal value.
Shows the current phase deviation of the Word Clock from the timecode master—in other words, the deviation between audio and MIDI.
Defines how your Core Audio hardware is synchronized to an external timecode master.
Defines the master (timecode type) that Logic Pro is synchronized to.
When selected, Logic Pro runs as the master until it receives a synchronization signal—either in the form of MTC, or from the Tempo Interpreter.
Auto-enable External Sync and Tap Tempo checkbox
Defines the frame rate, which applies to both transmitted and received timecode.
When selected (recommended), the incoming timecode is analyzed and the correct frame rate set automatically.
Auto detect format of MTC checkbox
Specifies how often Logic Pro checks for incoming timecode, in order to ensure synchronization integrity. In general, you should leave this option on “always.”
Defines the SMPTE offset for the project. As projects don’t always need to start precisely at bar 1, you can select any bar position to be played at the set SMPTE time.
Bar Position plays at SMPTE sliders
Shows the absolute time from the start of the project in the time display, rather than the actual SMPTE time.
Enable Separate SMPTE View Offset checkbox
Becomes available if you select the Enable Separate SMPTE View Offset checkbox.
Bar Position displayed as SMPTE sliders
Determines the first discrete MIDI output port for the MIDI Clock signal.
Determines the second discrete MIDI output port for the MIDI Clock signal.
Use to delay the transmission of MIDI Clock signals. Negative values mean that the MIDI Clock signal is transmitted earlier.
Activates the transmission of MIDI timecode.
Determines the MIDI output port for the MTC signal.
Allows transmission of MIDI Machine Control.
Controls Logic Pro by MIDI Machine Control and so-called Full Frame Messages.
Determines the MIDI clock transmission mode for synchronized MIDI devices.
Defines the musical position at which the MIDI Clock output should start.
Compensates for delays that can be introduced when using plug-ins.
You can instruct the Unitor8 to read or write SMPTE data.
Activates Refresh mode, where fresh timecode is generated, in sync with received timecode.
Define the SMPTE format that you want to use.
Specifies how long the synchronizer continues transferring MTC to the sequencer, after timecode ceases to be read.
Defines the television format for timecode burn-in.
VITC is written into two lines of the video picture, which are normally invisible. The lines should not be adjacent, and are usually situated between 12 and 20.
VITC is written into two lines of the video picture, which are normally invisible. The lines should not be adjacent, and are usually situated between 12 and 20.
Sets the size of the timecode counter window, which is burned in to the video picture.
Sets the style of the timecode counter window, which is burned in to the video picture.
Sets the position of the timecode counter window, which is burned in to the video picture.
Sets the position of the timecode counter window, which is burned in to the video picture.
Determines the global tuning of all software instruments. The default is concert pitch A (440 Hz).
Disables any tuning, and uses an equal tempered scale.
Activates a number of fixed tuning scales and keys.
Offers the most important historic tuning scales, as well as a few others.
Allows you to choose a global key (C-B) for the chosen scale. This provides an easy way to reference the chosen scale to any root note.
Allows you to detune each semitone in steps.
Determines the deviation (from the equal tempered scale) in the treble end of the sound. The higher the value, the farther down the low notes are tuned.
Determines the deviation (from the equal tempered scale) in the bass end of the sound. The higher the value, the farther down the low notes are tuned.
Allows you to set different Hermode Tuning (HMT) modes and degrees of effect.
Allows you to set different Hermode Tuning modes.
Allows you to set degrees of effect between 0% and 100%.
Allows you to choose a global key (C-B) for the chosen scale. This provides an easy way to reference the chosen scale to any root note.
Lists the basic keys of the project, including time and key signatures. You can add or edit signature events as you would in the Signature track.
View, create, delete, and rename signature sets. You can have up to nine variations in a project.
Drag signature values vertically to edit them, or double-click and enter a new value.
Add a time or key signature event, based on the selection in the pop-up menu.
Choose the signature type to be added when you click the Add Signature button.
Use screen controls to quickly modify the sound of the current patch. Click the "i" button to access parameter mappings, hardware assignments, and different Smart Control layouts.
Access parameter mappings and hardware assignments for the selected screen control. You can also choose different Smart Control layouts.
Select a screen control, which you can map to parameters or assign hardware controls to. You can also choose different Smart Control layouts.
Have the application choose a suitable mapping for the screen controls in the current Smart Control. You must have at least one plug-in inserted.
Compare your changes with the saved settings of the Smart Control, to hear how they affect the sound.
Turn the Arpeggiator on (inserts it on the channel strip) or off. When on, chords are played one note at a time rather than simultaneously.
Choose presets and adjust settings such as note order and octave range. You can also open the Arpeggiator plug-in.
Choose a different layout for the current Smart Control or choose Automatic to have the application determine a suitable mapping for the screen controls.
Show the Smart Controls for the selected track.
Show the Smart Controls for the master track.
Load and save settings for the chosen effect.
Deactivate the effect. Bypassed effects don’t drain system resources.
Lists all tempo changes and their position in the project. You can add or edit tempo events as you would in the Tempo track.
Add a tempo event based on the current project tempo and playhead position.
Shows all tempo changes, including those on the tempo curve. A tempo curve is a continuous transition between two tempi, which you can create in the Tempo track.
View, create, delete, and rename tempo sets. You can have up to nine variations in a project.
Drag tempo and position values vertically to edit them, or double-click and enter a new value.
Turn the metronome on or off. Click-hold, then drag, to adjust its volume.
Navigate backward or forward by one bar. You can Shift-click to jump 8 bars or click in the waveform overview to move there directly.
Start or stop playback of the audio file. You can also use the Space bar on your computer keyboard.
Shows the currently displayed bar number and the overall number of bars. Drag vertically, or double-click and enter a new value, to navigate numerically.
Shows the time signature. Drag vertically, or double-click and enter a new value, to edit the number of beats. Choose a note value from the pop-up menu.
Click along with the beat. You can also use the Tab key on your computer keyboard. The first click starts playback.
Shift the beat grid one beat left or right.
Remove any previously added tempo and signature information and start a fresh analysis.
Click to navigate. Orange frames indicate bars where you provided beat positions.
Select to replace the project tempo with the edited tempo information where the audio region is located.
Select to make the audio region follow the existing project tempo.
Allows you to gradually reduce or remove the edited tempo changes—up to a constant tempo value.
Have the number of contiguous taps define the time signature’s number of beats per bar.
Number of Taps defines Signature checkbox
Close the window and write the edited tempo information to the audio file.
Close the window without making any changes to the audio file.
Click in the waveform to set new, or move existing, beat positions. Click the orange numbers to remove your beat positions.
Increase the vertical zoom of the selected track. Any subsequently selected track will zoom to this level. Click again to reset the zoom.
Set the cycle area in the ruler to match the length of the region or marquee selection. Use the cycle to repeatedly play or record over this project section.
Duplicate the project section that falls within the locator positions in the ruler. The duplicated section is pasted at the right locator.
Remove all parts of a region that fall outside its marquee selection.
Divide selected regions or events at the playhead position.
Render the selected audio regions to a new audio track. The original audio regions are muted.
Render your project to a single audio file, or to multiple audio files. You can bounce to several different file formats simultaneously.
Use the Color palette to change the color of selected regions, channel strips, and takes.
Import an audio file into your project, placed at the playhead position of the selected track. Press B to work with the file in the Project Audio Browser.
Export regions and tracks as audio files, scores as MusicXML, or projects in multiple file formats.
Zoom to fit the selected regions or events into the available workspace. Click again to reset the zoom.
Move the playhead to the previous or next marker. Use markers for selection, playback, editing, and arrangement functions.
Divide selected regions or events at the locator positions in the ruler.
Remove silent passages from the audio region in the Strip Silence window.
Join selected regions. The regions can be on different tracks, but must be of the same type.
Expand or compress the selected region to match the locator positions in the ruler. Time stretching alters the tempo but not the pitch.
Cut the project section that falls within the locator positions in the ruler.
Insert a cut section at the playhead position.
Fill the project section that falls within the locator positions in the ruler with empty time.
Set the nudge value for moving selected regions or events.
Move selected regions or events by the chosen nudge value. You can also use the Option and Left and Right Arrow keys on your keyboard.
Move selected regions or events to the playhead position.
Fix selected regions or events to play at a specific time position—when synchronizing with film, for example.
Open group settings, which let you specify parameters that can be edited for multiple channel strips at the same time.
Disable channel strip groups so you can edit channel strip settings independent of the group.
Open Automation Quick Access (AQA) preferences. You can assign a MIDI controller, such as the mod wheel, to remotely control the active parameter on the selected track.
Click to show Hide buttons on track headers. Clicking the track Hide buttons, followed by this Hide button, hides those tracks.
Assign controllers—such as faders, knobs, and switches—to remotely control channel strip and plug-in settings.
Move the selected regions to the selected track.
Shuffle selected regions left or right.
Crossfade the overlapped area of two overlapping regions.
Transform an incoming MIDI note into a repeated MIDI note of the same pitch.
When recording in Cycle mode, click to temporarily use incoming notes to delete any matching notes in the region as the playhead passes over them.
Choose a tool for left-click actions. You can quickly revert to the Pointer tool by pressing the T key twice.
Choose a tool for Command-click actions.
Choose a tool for right-click actions.
Select, move, copy, resize, or loop regions, events, and other elements. The tool appearance changes based on function.
Create a region or event, or use to edit its length.
Delete a region, event, folder, marker, or other element.
Edit the name of a region, folder, marker, or other element.
Join regions or events by selecting and clicking them.
Play a region or event in isolation.
Silence a region or event. You can also use the Mute checkbox in the Region inspector.
Zoom a selected region or event. Click the background with the tool to revert to the normal zoom level.
Create, edit, or delete fades, or use to change the shape of fade curves. You can also use the Fade parameters in the Region inspector.
Select automation data and create nodes at region borders.
Bend the line between two automation points.
Select and edit region parts by dragging across them.
Edit the timing of audio files. You can also make flex edits by clicking the Flex button in the Tracks area.
Edit the length of an event.
Use for a number of tasks, including selection, in the Audio File Editor.
Correct the timing of notes by click-holding and choosing a quantization value.
Edit note velocity in the Piano Roll and Score Editors. Grab one or more notes, then drag vertically. Observe how the note changes color and its horizontal line resizes.
Graphically move events or global text objects.
Draw a separation line between notes on a staff to assign them to the predefined MIDI channels of the voices.
Change the size of a note or other symbol.
Assign an Environment object to the selected track in the Tracks area.
Export the score, or a section of the score, as an image or PDF file.
Edit multiple steps by clicking a start and end position on the lane, changing the values of the steps along the line.
Edit the length of a region or event.
Loop a region. You can also use the Loop checkbox in the Region inspector.
Adjust the amount of vibrato on notes in Flex Pitch mode, in the Audio Track Editor.
Adjust the amount of gain applied to notes in Flex Pitch mode, in the Audio Track Editor.
Use to add notes, based on defined time and pitch settings, in the Piano Roll Editor.
Contains buttons and displays for key project and application functions.
Move the playhead to the start of the project.
Move the playhead to a target bar or time position. Specify the position in the Go to Position dialog.
Move the playhead to the left locator shown in the ruler. The left locator defines the start point of the cycle area, used to repeatedly play or record over a section.
Move the playhead to the right locator shown in the ruler. The right locator defines the end point of the cycle area, used to repeatedly play or record over a section.
Move the playhead to the start of the first selected region or event.
Play from the start of the project.
Start playback from the leftmost visible point in the active workspace.
Play from Left Window Edge button
Start playback from the left locator shown in the ruler. The left locator defines the start point of the cycle area, used to repeatedly play or record over a section.
Start playback from the right locator shown in the ruler. The right locator defines the end point of the cycle area, used to repeatedly play or record over a section.
Start playback from the first selected region or event.
Move the playhead back one bar. Click-hold to fast rewind.
Move the playhead forward one bar. Click-hold to fast forward.
Stop playback or recording. Click when stopped to move the playhead to the project start point, or to the left locator shown in the ruler when in Cycle mode.
Start playback from the playhead position, or from the left locator shown in the ruler when in Cycle mode.
Pause playback or recording, until you click either the Pause or Play button.
Record to the selected track, or to multiple record-enabled tracks.
Capture the most recent performance, even if Logic was not recording while you were playing.
Indicates the playhead position in hours, minutes, seconds, and frames. Drag each element vertically to edit it, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the playhead position in bars, beats, divisions, and ticks. Drag each element vertically to edit it, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the left locator position in the ruler. Drag each element vertically to edit it, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the right locator position in the ruler. Drag each element vertically to edit it, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the project sample rate. Click the display, then choose a sample rate from the pop-up menu.
Indicates the autopunch area start and end points shown in the ruler. Drag each element vertically to edit it, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the autopunch area start and end points shown in the ruler. Drag each element vertically to edit it, or double-click and enter a new value.
