Indicates how the project playback speed is altered. Click the upper row to alter the mode and unit. Drag vertically in the lower row to edit the unit value, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates how the project playback speed is altered. Click the upper row to alter the mode and unit. Drag vertically in the lower row to edit the unit value, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the playback or recording speed. Drag vertically to speed up or slow down the tempo, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the total number of bars in the project. Drag vertically to move the end-of-project marker, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the key signature of the project. Choose a major or minor key signature from the pop-up menu.
Indicates the number of beats in a bar and the note value for one beat. Drag vertically to edit the value, or double-click and enter a new value.
Indicates the grid value used for displaying and editing in the Tracks area. Drag vertically to edit the value, or double-click and enter a new value.
Sends a MIDI panic message that stops transmission on all MIDI ports and channels. Click to reset, or double-click to stop MIDI event transmission.
Indicates system performance—CPU load and hard disk throughput.
Hear incoming audio with effects (wet signal), while recording the track without effects (dry signal).
Hear the input signal while recording. Before and after recording, you hear the previously recorded audio on the track.
Switch all channel strips between pre and post fader. Pre fader means that signals sent to aux channel strips are not affected by Volume fader movement; post fader means they are.
Limit the delay caused by some effects across the signal path. To set the limit, use the Limit slider in Audio preferences.
Move the left locator shown in the ruler to match the playhead position.
Set Left Locator by Playhead button
Move the right locator shown in the ruler to match the playhead position.
Set Right Locator by Playhead button
Move the left locator shown in the ruler to a target bar position, specified in the Set Locator dialog.
Move the right locator shown in the ruler to a target bar position, specified in the Set Locator dialog.
Swap Cycle and Skip Cycle modes. Use Cycle mode to repeatedly play, or record over, a section. Use Skip Cycle mode to skip that section during playback or recording.
Swap Left and Right Locators button
Move the cycle area to the left by a distance that matches the cycle range.
Move Locators Backward by Cycle Length button
Move the cycle area to the right by a distance that matches the cycle range.
Move Locators Forward by Cycle Length button
Turn Cycle mode on or off. Use to repeatedly play, or record over, the project section within the yellow cycle area that appears in the ruler.
Turn Autopunch mode on or off. Use the red area in the ruler, defined by the left and right punch locators, to record over a section.
Move the punch in locator shown in the ruler to match the playhead position.
Set Punch In Locator by Playhead button
Move the punch out locator shown in the ruler to match the playhead position.
Set Punch Out Locator by Playhead button
Replace an existing recording, or a portion of it, with a new recording.
Hear selected regions only during playback.
Turn External Synchronization mode on or off.
Hear a click at the project tempo during playback or recording. Click-hold for further options.
Set the overall project volume. You can also use the master channel strip's Volume fader.
Load patches and presets for the selected channel strip or plug-in type; start playing immediately. Loading a patch can affect multiple channel strips.
View and edit region and track settings, based on where you're working and the item selected. You can also set channel strip pan and volume, or add effects.
Open the Mixer, which shows channel strips for each track in the project. You can edit channel strip controls, add and edit plug-ins, and customize routing options.
Access editors—Audio Track, Audio File, Drummer, Piano Roll, Score, or Step Editor—based on the selected track type.
Open the Lists area, where you can view and edit MIDI events, markers, tempo changes, and signature events.
Open the Note Pads, where you can create, view, and edit project and track text notes.
Open the Browser area, where you can access audio and other media files. You can also import data and settings from other projects.
Open the Loop Browser, which contains prerecorded audio and software instrument loops you can add to your project.
Close the sheet and make the selected changes to the control bar.
Reset the control bar to either the factory layout or the user-saved layout. Option-click the button to override the user layout with the factory layout.
Save the current layout of the control bar. This layout is applied each time you create a new project, open a new main window, or click the Restore Defaults button.
Close the sheet without making any changes to the control bar.
Alter playback speed or playback speed and pitch, or transpose classic MIDI output.
Indicates the mode and frame rate of the incoming SMPTE format.
Show the toolbar, which contains buttons for key functions.
Show the Quick Help area. If the inspector is closed, Quick Help opens as a separate window.
Open the Smart Controls area, where you can quickly modify the sound of the current patch without having to edit individual channel strips or plug-ins.
Switch the ruler display between bars and beats, or hours, minutes, and seconds, or a combination of both. You can also open giant displays.
Open the Tuner, which you can use to tune instruments connected to your system.
Toggle the count-in between the setting defined in Record > Count-in and none.
Use to mute or solo the track's channel strip signal, arm the track for recording, and adjust volume or pan. You can also set a groove track, to which other tracks match their timing.
Render the track as an audio file. This reduces the processing power needed to play the track, especially for tracks that use complex effects.
Lock the track. You can't edit existing regions, create new regions, or record on the track.
Hide the track in the Tracks area; first click this button, then click the Hide button above the track headers.
Choose the channel strip, Smart Control, or plug-in parameter that you want to automate.
Set how channel strip and plug-in changes are handled during recording and playback.
Play back all automation that exists on the track. You can't change the value of the chosen parameter by moving controls.
Drag to adjust all automation on the track in one go. Move the pointer off the field to see the value of the parameter at the playhead position.
Move a control to change the value of the chosen parameter. When you release the control, the parameter reverts to the original value.
Move a control to change the value of the chosen parameter. When you release the control, the parameter does not revert to the original value.
Erase the existing automation on the track as the playhead passes over it or record the new control movement.
Take the track offline to save processing resources.
Turn off all Flex Time editing properties on the track.
Use for drums and percussion. Slices the audio at transient markers, playing each slice at its original speed.
Use as a starting point for all kinds of rhythmic material and Apple Loops. Based on the Apple Loops time-stretching algorithm.
Use for solo vocals and monophonic solo instruments. Delivers high sonic quality, but the recording needs to be relatively dry, without audible reverberation.
Use for solo vocals and monophonic solo instruments. Delivers high sonic quality, but the recording needs to be relatively dry, without audible reverberation.
Use for creative purposes with special effects.
Use for percussive material, or for interesting creative effects on all material.
Adjust the track zoom level. Command-drag to zoom all tracks. Shift-click to reset all tracks to the default zoom level.
Indicates that the track is accessed by a control surface connected to your system.
Show or hide automation subtracks. Use to automate multiple channel strip and plug-in parameters for the same track.
Use to include the transients of all regions on the track as reference points during quantization. You can also use the Q-Reference checkbox in the Track inspector.
Choose algorithms that alter the timing and pitch of audio on the track. Use the Region inspector's Flex checkbox to edit regions individually.
Use to quantize and edit the pitch of audio.
Turn flex on or off for the track. When turned on, you can access Flex Pitch and Flex Time algorithms in the pop-up menu.
Switch between track-based and region-based automation. When automation is on, you can record or play channel strip, Smart Control, and plug-in changes in the Tracks area.
Indicates that this track is the groove track, to which other tracks match their timing when their Match Groove Track checkbox is selected.
Select to match this track's timing to the groove track, which is indicated by a star in the track header.
Show or hide subtracks. Use the controls on the main track to control all subtracks in the track stack.
Use to edit the timing of audio, by compressing or expanding the time between specified markers in an audio region.
Use to quantize and edit the pitch of audio.
Logic Pro chooses the best Flex Time algorithm based on an automatic analysis.
Set the track as a groove track. You can match the timing of other tracks to this groove track, by selecting their Match Groove Track checkbox.
Control-click to choose an icon for the track.
Provides a quick way of applying proportional adjustments to existing automation for Volume, Pan, and Send levels.
Records relative changes to Volume, Pan, and Send levels, independent of any existing absolute automation.
Shows the signal output during playback. Watch the level meter and the peak level display during playback or recording to see if signal clipping occurs.
